replies.bodyText:
You are correct, this I think is the last one. I would leave it as written:
a) To be be clear of rollBack state (setting with try/finally after each call to doRollback
b) This way you can put a breakpoint in a debugger, or add more logic after this catch and be clear what is going on....
A more interesting question, if you look at the previous logic, should I set rolledBack = true before calling the doRollback method?

replies.bodyText:
See line 126, we are trying to prevent duplicate rollback.
Aside: Trying for minimal change the previous tested logic. With more time I would refactor into multiple methods to clearly document what each branch of logic is trying to do etc...

timeline.bodyText: Is the intention that the code continues?
timeline.author: josegar74

replies.bodyText: no, reading the previous logic I should have a return. Idea was to change the check to be postive, general principle to improve legibility.
replies.author: jodygarnett

timeline.bodyText: In previous code when a listener failed, seem no further processing, now all are processed and thrown the exception of the last one that fails. It can be fine, but want to confirm that is the intention.
timeline.author: josegar74

replies.bodyText:
Yes that was my intension, trying to read the code and check the listener api contracts and make the application more predictable.
There was nothing explicit in the api about allowing listeners to halt the notification process (sometimes in core java api listeners are allowed to return "true" if they have addressed an event to prevent further processing).
replies.author: jodygarnett

timeline.bodyText: To confirm no need to call _context.clear() as this code runs in a custom thread?
timeline.author: josegar74

replies.bodyText:
This may be a case where a task is sharing a context, so calling clear() breaks another task.
Long term it may be smart to implement reference counting, or a context wrapper, when providing the same context to more than one thread.
replies.author: jodygarnett

timeline.author: josegar74

replies.bodyText: I expect more instances of clear() can be added over time, especially if you can confirm how it is used.
